item.title: On the conservatism of academics
item.description:

“I’ve said before that I think that most academics doing similar jobs to me are *de facto* conservatives. A short thread on what I mean by this.”

dave
item.description:
dave on Twitter

“Latest codex demo from @openai. Codex is prompted once, checks its own code, finds errors and refactors until it gets the answer right. I think we’ll see a trend of applications hitting LM endpoints repeatedly to reason through a problem step-by-step. https://t.co/BKSus2Gr82”

URL: https://twitter.com/dmvaldman/status/1587200350477393921

item.title: Ted Underwood / @TedUnderwood@scholar.social
item.description:
Ted Underwood / @TedUnderwood@scholar.social on Twitter

“Honestly, ML research has as many twists-per-week now as a television series. It can be read for entertainment. Case in point: Instead of just generating, let’s edit text. And let’s think of editing as a process of *reversing corruption,* so it can be modeled ... with diffusion.”

URL: https://twitter.com/Ted_Underwood/status/1587291020965957633

“Our method, Forgetful Causal Masking(FCM), combines masked language modeling (MLM) and causal language modeling (CLM) by masking out randomly selected past tokens layer-wisely using attention mask.”

item.title: Hao Liu
item.description:
Hao Liu on Twitter

“Our largest 8B model matches the score of PaLM with an average score of 64%, despite the fact that PaLM is trained on a much larger dataset (780B tokens) of high-quality conversation and webpage data, while ours is trained on the smaller C4 dataset (180B tokens).”
